emotes.msg: The undead General who wrote this book seems to be very deeply involved in Emperor Geraine's plans. As you'll see, the information is disturbing, but may be the key needed to thwart whatever it is Emperor Geraine is up to.
There you are.  This was gained from a powerful Revenant you say?  He would appear to have been several millenia old!  I wonder if there are others of his antiquity still walking Dereth?
I translated this best I could, but the level of complexity in this research is impressive.
There is, however, one part that may point to this factory they speak of. Perhaps Sir Donovan can make use of it to track it down.
Here you go. Good luck
Well, this explains a lot, and raises even more questions. I did not think the plight of the Empyreans was related to the actions of Emperor Geraine, but I guess it was.
There's a Royal Investigator, Sir Daeglan, I believe his name is, that was researching any information he could find on Emperor Geraine's actions. He may well be interested in this.
Last I heard, he was in the camp next to the Lost City of Neftet, researching the ritual site that was uncovered there.

The undead General who wrote this book seems to be very deeply involved in Emperor Geraine's plans. As you'll see, the information is disturbing, but may be the key needed to thwart whatever it is Emperor Geraine is up to.
There's a Royal Investigator, Sir Daeglan, I believe his name is, that was researching any information he could find on Emperor Geraine's actions. He may well be interested in this.
Last I heard, he was in the camp next to the Lost City of Neftet, researching the ritual site that was uncovered there.
This has to be one of the more disturbing tomes I have ever transcribed. If it is true, then there truly is no telling what Emperor Geraine is capable of.

The undead General who wrote this book seems to be very deeply involved in Emperor Geraine's plans. As you'll see, the information is disturbing, but may be the key needed to thwart whatever it is Emperor Geraine is up to.
There's a Royal Investigator, Sir Daeglan, I believe his name is, that was researching any information he could find on Emperor Geraine's actions. He may well be interested in this.
Last I heard, he was in the camp next to the Lost City of Neftet, researching the ritual site that was uncovered there.
My apologies. There is very little in this tome, as the last of it is damaged. I recovered what I could.

The undead General who wrote this book seems to be very deeply involved in Emperor Geraine's plans. As you'll see, the information is disturbing, but may be the key needed to thwart whatever it is Emperor Geraine is up to.
There's a Royal Investigator, Sir Daeglan, I believe his name is, that was researching any information he could find on Emperor Geraine's actions. He may well be interested in this.
This seems to be some sort of report about those strange Bloodstones I've heard about, up by the Gurogs.
There's one of Borelean's Royal Knights, Sir Donovan, who was doing research on the Bloodstones. I'd bet he'd be interested in this.
Last I heard, he was up at the encampment along the borders of the Gurog's frozen valley. You should be able to find him there.
Indeed, this is the runic script of old Dericost, a language not used in well over 5000 years.  A moment - I shall transcribe a copy for you into Roulean.
There's a Royal Investigator, Sir Daeglan, I believe his name is, that was researching any information he could find on Emperor Geraine's actions. He may well be interested in this.
Last I heard, he was in the camp next to the Lost City of Neftet, researching the ritual site that was uncovered there.
Hm. This appears to be a portalspace coordinate. Such things are not within my knowledge. You might want to seek out my colleague Marisa bint Fuya.
She would be able to cast a portal to this location. Unfortunately, she's on sabbatical, and has gone to the town of Plateau.
Be warned, though - you will need a substantial party to reach the Lost City, and should you die...
You will be unable to reenter the caves to recover your equipment. Be certain you are prepared before you ask Mairisa to cast the portal!

Ah, but this is not the language of Dericost.  Do you see the sharp, triangular shapes the characters are composed of? This is almost certainly the written word of the Falatacot, a far older, and far less understood culture.
Fanzen San, in Hebian-To, would be able to translate this for you.
I can indeed translate this for you into Roulean.
This is... fascinating. This work seems to explain what the Gelidites were doing in their long exile.
My apologies, but I cannot read this.  It appears to be the script of ancient Empyrea.  You should bring this to Bretself the translator, in Cragstone.
My apologies, but I cannot read this.  It appears to be the script of ancient Empyrea.  You should bring this to Bretself the translator, in Cragstone.
My apologies, but I cannot read this.  It appears to be the language of the ancient Falatacot.  You should bring this to Fanzen San, in Hebian-To.
Oh dear...
This doesn't bode well. No, not at all. Take a look for yourself.

I fear I cannot help you with this. You see that this writing style is like our own? It appears to be the script used by the High Empyrean culture of the Age of Lore. My specialty is the runic language of Dericost. You should bring this to Bretself the translator, in Cragstone.

I fear I cannot help you with this. You see that this writing style is like our own? It appears to be the script used by the High Empyrean culture of the Age of Lore. My specialty is the runic language of Dericost. You should bring this to Bretself the translator, in Cragstone.

I fear I cannot help you with this. You see that this writing style is like our own? It appears to be the script used by the High Empyrean culture of the Age of Lore. My specialty is the runic language of Dericost. You should bring this to Bretself the translator, in Cragstone.
This note seems to be written on cured skin... Not human skin, but something similar.  The contents of the note are quite disturbing, and written in an archaic dialect of ancient Dericostian.

I fear I cannot help you with this. You see that this writing style is like our own? It appears to be the script used by the High Empyrean culture of the Age of Lore. My specialty is the runic language of Dericost. You should bring this to Bretself the translator, in Cragstone.

I fear I cannot help you with this. You see that this writing style is like our own? It appears to be the script used by the High Empyrean culture of the Age of Lore. My specialty is the runic language of Dericost. You should bring this to Bretself the translator, in Cragstone.
Aerfalle... I have seen this name before. An adventurer brought me a note from Rytheran, the Revenant of the Mage Academy near Mount Esper. It was addressed to an Aerfalle. But this... a moment...
Heavens and earth! This speaks of the last Shadow War, and in grave detail. I am... profoundly disturbed by the sights this Aerfalle has witnessed.
Ew! What IS that?
Take it to Bretslef in Cragstone. I don't want to touch it!
%n grabs a flask of water and hurriedly scrubs her hands.
Ew! What IS that?
Take it to Bretslef in Cragstone. I don't want to touch it!
%n grabs a flask of water and hurriedly scrubs her hands.
Ew! What IS that?
Take it to Bretslef in Cragstone. I don't want to touch it!
%n grabs a flask of water and hurriedly scrubs her hands.
Ah yes, this is interesting. This came from a Mu-Miyah, you say. Curious. This would seem to be some sort of memoir.
I wonder what would provoke such soul searching? Although I have noted that the undead seem prone to rambling reminiscence... I suppose when one is that old, it becomes inevitable.
This is most intriguing! It would seem we have have allies in our war against the forces of Bael'Zharon. Of a sort, anyway.
This is useful. There is an army of undead gathering somewhere in the wilderness. Odd that they have not been seen yet.
It would seem they do not all get along. Old grudges, I suppose.
Heavens and earth, do you know what this is? This is nothing less than the undeads' own analysis of the Shadows' activity.
I have little doubt that this information will be invaluable in the near future. You may have given us a crucial edge.
Your pardon, but I must leave soon to confer with my colleagues and the Consortium of Archmages...
Hm, interesting. Looks like you caught this monster in the middle of writing a report to its superior.
Well. This undead certainly thinks the world owes her. I can't imagine how obnoxious she'd be in person. If there's anything worse than a smelly abomination, it's a smarmy smelly abomination.
Ew! What IS that?
Take it to Bretslef in Cragstone. I don't want to touch it!
%n grabs a flask of water and hurriedly scrubs her hands.
Ew! What IS that?
Take it to Bretslef in Cragstone. I don't want to touch it!
%n grabs a flask of water and hurriedly scrubs her hands.

I fear I cannot help you with this. You see that this writing style is like our own? It appears to be the script used by the High Empyrean culture of the Age of Lore. My specialty is the runic language of Dericost. You should bring this to Bretself the translator, in Cragstone.
Magnificent! The dates in this journal stretch back to the last Shadow War. What an invaluable asset to our studies! It will take some time to go over this thoroughly. Here are the last few entries.

I fear I cannot help you with this. You see that this writing style is like our own? It appears to be the script used by the High Empyrean culture of the Age of Lore. My specialty is the runic language of Dericost. You should bring this to Bretself the translator, in Cragstone.

I fear I cannot help you with this. You see that this writing style is like our own? It appears to be the script used by the High Empyrean culture of the Age of Lore. My specialty is the runic language of Dericost. You should bring this to Bretself the translator, in Cragstone.
Ah, yes, this appears to be a unique teleport spell. Give me a moment, and I can teach it to you.

I fear I cannot help you with this. You see that this writing style is like our own? It appears to be the script used by the High Empyrean culture of the Age of Lore. My specialty is the runic language of Dericost. You should bring this to Bretself the translator, in Cragstone.
Hrm. Well, the letters of this are in the High Empyrean language of the Age of Lore. However, they don't seem to form any words.

I fear I cannot help you with this. You see that this writing style is like our own? It appears to be the script used by the High Empyrean culture of the Age of Lore. My specialty is the runic language of Dericost. You should bring this to Bretself the translator, in Cragstone.
My apologies, but I cannot read this.  It appears to be the language of the ancient Falatacot.  You should bring this to Fanzen San, in Hebian-To.
I do not recognize this language at all... Try talking to Diyas al-Yat, here in Zaikhal.  He's an odd man who spends his time studying the Virindi.
I do not recognize this language at all... Try talking to Diyas al-Yat, here in Zaikhal.  He's an odd man who spends his time studying the Virindi.
I do not recognize this language at all... Try talking to Diyas al-Yat, here in Zaikhal.  He's an odd man who spends his time studying the Virindi.
What is this?  Perhaps Diyas could make some sense of it...
What is this?  Perhaps Diyas could make some sense of it...
What is this?  Perhaps Diyas could make some sense of it...
I am sorry, but I cannot read this.  Try talking to the Hebian-To translator, Fanzen San.
An interesting read, a bit fanatical in spot. I have made notes where they are applicable.
Will wonders never cease? This book was difficult because of the damage wrought upon it. As well the text itself was written in a variation of Dericost, akin to that of the Gelid.
This is a personal missive, written very recently. I'd be interested to see if there were more like it.
A second note written in the same hand, and like the first a missive written recently. What are they working on?
The World Shaper. I wonder what that title means? Keep bringing these to me as you find them, please.
Well it appears that these letters are beginning to take on a more active ken. I'd be interested in seeing if there were anymore.
This must be the last of them. It has an air of finality to it. I wonder what sacrifice the writer is speaking about.
Kuyiza begins translating and transcribing the text for you, happily chatting along as she works.
It has been such a long while since I have had something new to work with. People usually bring me bits of parchment from Frore... not that I mind Frore...
Sometimes they bring me something about the undead scholar Rytheran... but I've seen most of what is said in those texts already...
Then there was that whole Elemental business... well... I wasn't able to leave my cottage because they were everywhere for a time...
And who would have thought that the Dericost would help us seal up the tunnels of the... oh my...
Kuyiza stops mid sentence, rapidly finishes her transcriptions and seals the tome with wax.
You are working for the Shadow Hunter Killcrane, yes? Quickly, take this directly to him. Don't dawdle. What is in this tome is of great import.
Kuyiza bint Zayi squints as she reads the inscription on the token.
This seems to be an inscription from Rytheran to Aerfalle, promising his undying love.
Kuyiza bint Zayi the Translator snickers.
Undying love indeed...
I know people who would be interested in this. Please, allow me to reward you for bringing this to me.
Kuyiza bint Zayi squints as she reads the inscription on the token.
This seems to be an inscription from Rytheran to Aerfalle, promising his undying love.
Kuyiza bint Zayi the Translator snickers.
Undying love indeed...
I know people who would be interested in this. Please, allow me to reward you for bringing this to me.
Kuyiza bint Zayi squints as she reads the inscription on the token.
This seems to be an inscription from Rytheran to Aerfalle, promising his undying love.
Kuyiza bint Zayi the Translator snickers.
Undying love indeed...
I know people who would be interested in this. Please, allow me to reward you for bringing this to me.
This journal is written in the runic script of old Dericost, a language not used in well over 5000 years. A moment - I shall transcribe a copy for you into Roulean.
There you are. This sounds to me like more lore from that ancient graveyard. Did you find anything with this journal? Perhaps they are related.
Here you go.
Indeed, this is the runic script of old Dericost, a language not used in well over 5000 years... Save for this letter, which looks newly written...
Kuyiza bint Zayi looks slightly troubled.

This was found on Rytheran's Apprentice? It seems Rytheran is up to something involving that ancient graveyard and some book that was powerful enough to scare even the ancient Dericost into not using it.
Kuyiza bint Zayi shudders.
Here, see for yourself.
I am a scholar of a certain era of Empyrean history, the time of the Millennium War.  If your text is of Dericost, Haebrous, or early Yalain, I may be able to translate it.

changelog.comment: Weenie exported from ACEmulator world database using ACE.Adapter
